>>18829263
Pancetta is sometimes used but not always, no, it's not the same thing as bacon. But if you can't find pancetta then just skip it instead of replacing it with bacon. Not all traditional recipes call for pancetta. It's equally good to just go sofritto > mixed minced meat > tomato puré > red wine > water and herbs. My dad is from Bologna

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: it's more similar to ham than it is to bacon. it's salt-cured pork belly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
pancetta is for sandwiches

Bolognese is one version of ragù but the idea is minced meat tomato sauce. Use any recipe you'd like. Italian food is very diverse from region and from families.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829263
bacon is brined and then smoked, pancetta is just cured. It has a VERY different flavor to bacon or raw pork belly, jamon is the closest comparison I can make to the taste of pancetta

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
pancetta tesa is usually bit saltier and drier than bacon or pancetta arrotolata
its good and worth getting if a recipe calls for it
it might not be the easiest thing to get a hold of depending on where you are, but any italian import store/good deli should be able to get you some.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829545
>bacon is made from pork belly, a very fatty cut
>pancetta is made from pork belly, a very fatty cut
>ham is back leg, a lean cut
Yeah, obviously pancetta is more similar to ham than to bacon.
>>18829744
>bacon is brined and then smoked, pancetta is just cured.
Both are salt-cured, but pancetta is usually not smoked. The difference is in the smoke. The reason you say they taste is very different and pancetta is closer to jamon is you're probably used to shit bacon that is cured in a hurry with lots of nitrites.

An alcoholic in the strictest terms is somebody who has an impulsive addiction to alcohol. Usually due to the genetic component which is often comorbid with OCD, ADHD, autism and similar such illnesses. These are people who are likely to become addicted to many things such as substance abuse (including alcohol), food, hoarding, etc. Then there are people who struggle to give up drinking due to the significance it plays in their lives, perhaps it's a centerpiece of their social lives or perhaps they use it to relieve themselves after a stressful job, and if these lifestyle factors were removed, their need for alcohol would be gone. I wouldn't call these people alcoholics in the traditional sense, so borderline alcoholic seems like a fair term to me.

That's what I told them, that at that price point, they're looking at a hand grinder. My mother has arthritis, and my father is lazy, so I know if I get them a hand grinder, they'll never use it. Especially since they'd need to grind a lot of coffee, since just the two of them by themselves drink an entire pot in the morning.
>>18821662
This is probably the best option for them, but they likely won't go for it. I don't know if I'd be able to convince them to drop $100 for a used grinder. I may just buy it for them and hope they'll use it.

My parents' coffee situation is weird and, I think, a little bit funny. When I was growing up, they would drink shitty pre-ground Yuban or whatever they'd buy in bulk at Costco. About fifteen years ago, I got a part time at Starbucks, and got them a free bag of a coffee they sell called Casi Cielo, a seasonal Guatemalan coffee they sell, and probably the best whole bean coffee Starbucks carries. They fell in love with it, and asked me to hoard my free bags of coffee and ship it to them, instead of flipping it on eBay as I usually did. I haven't worked at Starbucks in about a decade, but my dad will still go to the local stores and buy up their entire supply whenever it's available, and now it's all they drink and told me they can't really stand the shitty pre-ground supermarket stuff. If they run out of that coffee, they'll switch to tea. When I visited them yesterday, I offered to grind their coffee with my hand grinder, but my mom stopped me because she immediately knew it would make a huge difference to have fresh burr-ground coffee, and she sort of didn't want to know, because she knew the financial rabbit hole coffee snobbery can lead to. They're reluctant to try better beans or better grinders, or better brew methods because they don't want to "have to" start spending more money on their morning coffee.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18823549
A faster, more even extraction is still preferable to a slower uneven one. Its not all that coarse of a grind fwiw, you're just used to looking at massive amounts of fines all over the bed. Better grinders(the anon above is either using a zp6 or kafatek flat) with more narrow particle distributions will let you get away with coarser grinds, but tastier cups because you're more evenly extracting the coffee.
>This shows exactly the “common knowledge” curve I was talking about earlier; if you grind too fine, average extraction yield goes down because your extraction becomes more uneven.
https://coffeeadastra.com/2020/04/02/why-cant-we-grind-coffee-finer-for-pour-over/
>Whenever too many coffee fines get trapped in the pores of a paper filter, the drip rate of a coffee brew can go down drastically. This is not only a problem because the brew becomes much longer: the bigger issue is that whatever water is still able to pass through will do so along smaller, and unchanging paths through the filter. This means that large regions of the coffee bed will potentially stop receiving fresh water, and will remain under extracted, while other regions will receive the bulk of the flow and contribute astringency or other unpleasant flavors caused by over extraction.
https://coffeeadastra.com/2021/03/04/the-four-rules-of-optimal-coffee-percolation/

>>18827079
>The name Champagne on a Cognac bottle refers to its origin, namely the growth area the grapes were grown in. There are six growth areas–or “terroirs”–in total, and the two that are considered to produce the finest eau-de-vie are named Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. These two premium terroirs have soil that compares to the soil of the Champagne region in Northern France. Hence the shared name.

>A Cognac is called a “Fine Champagne Cognac” when it contains a blend of eaux-de-vie from both Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. At least 50% of the blend have to be from the Grande Champagne. When the word Champagne is used on a Cognac, it will either be preceded by the word, Grande, Petite, or Fine. This simply denotes the terroir in which the grapes were grown.

I wouldn’t say I’ve noticed any cheese or mushroom, but I’ll take note of that and see what I can spot when I have my next glass later on. With my example there’s a lot of green grape skin going on though. And I definitely wouldn’t call it slow to open up, I can pretty much drink it immediately after pouring my glass but I like to take my time as the nose really is something. I typically buy Armagnac that’s been bottled about 30 years after the date it has been distilled (kinda my sweet spot, though I do have both younger and older), and I also only buy single vintage (i.e. bottles with the year stamped on them instead of the age of the product). My current Delord is 39 years however (distilled 1982, bottled 2021) and I’d happily buy it again. The only thing that annoys me about Delord is the wax they use to seal the cap is a LOT harder than literally any other Armagnac I’ve ever had to open, that said it’s a small price to pay for what’s a very affordable product in my opinion, especially given the age.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829472
I typically use a chefs knife; I score a line where I need the cap to separate from the bottle by gently running the blade around the circumference where the bottom of the bottle cap meets the glass, then I use the back of the knife to crack the wax. Don’t worry about damaging the cork, the cork itself is attached to a plastic cap and there’s no need to remove the wax from the cap. See picrel, that’s my 1982 Delord. I’m pretty OCD so I gun for a clean cut as pictured since I like my bottles looking nice. This takes experience though. The first time you do it you’re gonna be messy, so do it on a big empty table or kitchen top where you’ve got plenty of space so you can subsequently wipe all the chipped pieces of wax off with ease. Enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829472
Oh and re: the ABV, it’s honestly fine. Most Armagnac is ABV’d @ 40% (you can get higher), and I’ve had some pretty solid whisky at 40% even though I generally lean a wee bit higher for my favourites. I just had my Delord with my partner and we both agree no cheese or mushroom in the nose, palate and finish, lol. Looking at my tasting notes though, this is what I wrote: nose: extremely grape-y, like sniffing a well packed bouquet of fruits and berries packed in a basket held together by UHU glue; palate: sweet, minty and clinical, hard to pinpoint individual flavours, there’s something synthetic about the flavour but in a way I very much enjoy, it just tastes super clean; finish: the synthetic part really comes out here, plasticky but damn it’s addictive (bits of the UHU glue nose come out here on your taste buds, and just like UHU glue, it’s god damn addictive). This definitely won’t be everyone’s cup of tea, but god damn am I always in a heightened state of zen whenever I take my shot from this bottle.

>>18829703
lol yeah. Laubade does that, there’s a cloth string a few mm wide under the wax which you can just pull to get the fucker off. The problem with Delord isn’t the lack of string though, it’s that the wax is like fucking porcelain i.e. really hard. My older bottles of Laubade had no string but even despite that the wax was super easy to peel off. I typically don’t ever leave a bottle open for more than three months so I don’t have an issue with ageing becoming a problem. I typically drink one shot a day with my significant other (we do have one or two breaks a week though), sometimes we share one shot, sometimes we have a shot each; so with my rule of four open bottles at once that pretty much guarantees each bottle will finished within three months. I devised this rule mostly because for whisky it can be very unpredictable how well a bottle ages, and in my experience it’s not uncommon for shit to go downhill fast once the bottle is about 50% empty with all that air mucking about inside. Funnily enough I find Armagnac holds much better than whisky; I once had a bottle open for over a year and I still thoroughly enjoyed it. But like my current Glenfiddich 15 VAT 03 that’s open, I can tell I’m enjoying it a wee bit less now that the bottle is down to its remainder 35%. Still solid, but not quite as phenomenal as when the cap first came off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
heres a recipe I made for a friend for my lasagna.

I never used a written recipe and learned from watching someone else make it. They never used a written recipe either.

all amounts were pulled out of my ass based on a best guess for the recipe. because the amounts of many of the seasonings don't matter that much. The person I gave it to said it was the best lasagna they had ever had. they had no trouble making it and never questioned me on exact measurements.

2 lbs. sweet and/or hot Italian sausage
1 package Lasagna Noodles
1 Table spoon olive oil
2 16oz. cans diced or crushed stewed tomatoes
2 or 3 lbs. Mozzarella cheese
Italian seasoning
dried chopped parsley
2 or 3 pints ricotta cheese
2 or 3 eggs
1 white onion medium to large
6 to 8 medium size mushrooms
2 or 3 cloves fresh garlic

Mix the 2 or 3 eggs, 2 or 3 tablespoons parsley, and Ricotta cheese together.

Chop the Mushrooms.

Boil the noodles in a large saucepan with the oil, and 1 tsp. salt in the water,
cook until still tough. drain and refill pan with cold water to keep noodles from
sticking together.

Coarse chop the onion, smash and finely dice 1 or 2 cloves of garlic.
Remove the sausage casing, and break up the sausage in a frying pan.
Brown the sausage with 2/3 the onion and all the garlic, salt and pepper to taste.
Drain off the grease.

In a 2 quart sauce pan combine the Stewed tomatoes, 1 tsp. Italian seasoning, the rest of the onion, 1 crushed and finely chopped clove of garlic, the mushrooms, and the Sausage.
bring to boil and then simmer about 15 minutes.

Arrange in layers in a ungreased 9x13" pan: sauce, ricotta cheese, mozzarella, and pasta.
Top the last layer with a generous amount of mozzarella.
Bake at 350 for 20 to 25 minutes or until sauce bubbles and the cheese is slightly brown.

I understand that. I'm saying your written recipe doesn't fall into OP's complaint because you actually provided ranges of measurements for everything to help give a concept of proper ratios to the person following the recipe. You never say, "Put in the appropriate amount of cheese," for instance, and instead give an approximate amount of cheese which would be appropriate within a range, and you did the same thing for every seasoning as well. Your recipe is better written than one which just says things like "to taste."

>he can't season food without detailed exact instructions.
It's helpful for a recipe to impart baseline ratios and amounts to work with so you understand the intended outcome and aren't just winging it completely your first time through. The latter has a greater potential for user error and recipe failure or waste.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
dal tadka over rice
3 servings
>cup dry lentils ($1)
>half an onion (80¢)
>quarter cup tomato (50¢)
>cup dry rice (10¢)
>optional: teaspoon or so of cilantro. (~20¢)
>optional: a curry leaf or two (basically free if bought in bulk)
>2 cloves garlic, equal amount of ginger (~10¢)
>spices (1 Bay leaf, 1 black cardamom, 2 green cardamom, 2 cloves, teaspoon cumin, teaspoon coriander, teaspoon cayenne, teaspoon turmeric, salt) (basically free if you buy in bulk)
>water (basically free)
soak lentils in water 30 minutes
mince garlic and ginger. chop onion fine. if using whole canned tomato, also chop fine.
get rice cookin'.
heat like a tablespoon of ghee or oil in a pan until it just starts to smoke, then take it off the heat. throw in the spices and the curry leaf. be sure to crack the cardamom pods (but don't crack them completely in half, cause you should pull out that black cardamom before eating). let it hang out in the hot oil for a minute or two. this is called "tempering" or "blooming," it generally makes spices taste stronger. common technique in Indian cooking.
throw in the garlic, ginger and onion, and salt. cook a few minutes, until you get a little browning. add lentils and 1½ to 2 cups of water. quick simmer for half an hour.
towards the end, add the tomato and the chopped cilantro. cook a few minutes more. pull out the bay leaf and black cardamom (and the green cardamom if you can find it, but don't worry too much about the green cardamom)
serve over rice

you got protein, veggies, vitamins and calories for like $1.40 a serving

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18828777

Partially. I agree with him one thing; Japanese knives, and more specifically carbon steel Japanese knives with a HRC above 60, aren't really worth it at all. Between the increased maintenance and need to use stones to really get them sharp, it's not worth it. The whole thing about skill isn't an issue, anybody can use a whetstone with a bit of practice, but the extra effort involved especially in honing make it impractical, at least in a western cooking culture context.

You can buy a 8" victorinox chef's knife, and it will perform just as good in actual culinary applications as a more expensive knife, but IMO large stamped blades just feed cheap and flimsy in the hand. For something that your going to use every single day, I would pay a bit more for it to feel good to use.

So if you don't care about anything other than pure utilitarian performance, yes Victorinox will serve you well. If you want somthing that feel better in the hand, buy German, and if you want Japanese, buy Global.

>>18826611
Although that sounds nice and it's a meme, it's still a meme.

Try this: A bag of rice, chicken stock bouillon cubes (I like Knorr), oil (I like olive oil, I believe the seed oil meme), and multiple hot sauces.

>Take a pot
>Put in oil
>Heat it up
>Put rice in
>stir
>Toast rice until it starts to brown a little, NOT black
>Add water
>Add bouillon cube
>When it starts to boil turn it down
>Turn off after about 15 or so minutes depends on rice and amount
>let it sit for a few minutes
>perfect rice
Toasting rice means you don't have to wash it, or at least that's what I've learned.
The sauces will allow you to get a different flavor each time. I recommend A1 Steak sauce, green tabasco sauce, and sriracha to start off with..

If you want to get fancy, add half an onion as you're toasting, before adding rice to let it get cooked more, and then add pic related, its only like $0.50. That's how you can make an easy mexican rice.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18827815
Not really. Regular corn sugar is roughly 35% fructose and 65% glucose, high fructose corn sugar is around 40-45% fructose. Since fructose is bad for you, clearly high fructose corn sugar must be hella bad. Except that the sugar in that "healthy" apple is 50% fructose, making that 45% "high fructose" corn sugar practically a health food by comparison.

The big deal with high fructose corn sugar is it is *much* cheaper than other sources of sugar, making it cost effective to put in absolutely every fucking thing, and that's why it's bad - not because of the fructose, but because it's cheaper than just about anything else that goes in food.

Thai curry flavorings really need the fatty coconut base to temper the heat and carry flavor properly. There are variations commonly referred to as "jungle curry" or "forest curry" which exclude coconut because they originate from areas where coconuts were not traditionally available; but these dishes suck ass. Panang incorporates peanuts, possibly lessening the reliance on coconut, but recipes will vary. Yellow curries typically contain familiar Indian/British spice mixes, though relatively heavy use of coriander can cause a soapy taste.

My best friend is Jewish so I grew up eating a lot of their recipes. As for shakshuka being Jewish...uh, you're going to find a lot of contention on its origins lol

Definitely recommend dry blistering the vegetables in a pan or under a broiler first and you can use something like Caldo de Tomate to kinda cheat the process and have a tomatoey broth to build off of.

Something to keep in mind is that jewish food can very easily turn out very heavy and as a result you want to just....sit...afterward lol

please show us what you end up making!

but i will convince you to eat as few animal products as humanly possible.

animals are sentient beings that feel pain and fear. meat on an aesthetic level is just disgusting. think about the pure beauty of a stalk of celery. just plant fiber, water, cellulose

the only thing that will truly convince you though is to cook good vegan food. but don't look up vegan recipes, you're just going to get garbage health food.

in the end, it's the morally right thing to do. any "arguments" in favour of eating meat are very easily dismantled. anyone who doesn't eat meat has heard all the broscience, cope, mental gymnastics and cognitive dissonance so many times

if you love animals, you wouldn't support what's being done to them

So I've had people rant and rave at me for ages about how amazing rice cookers are
Me, I'm just a regular idiot who cooks rice on a stovetop. The directions say, equal parts water, cook 15 minutes, don't take the lid off. So that's what I do and the rice is cooked and perfect in 15 minutes.

Then I got a rice cooker for christmas, I'd always wanted one, I was pretty excited.

And you know what? It's fucking crap. It cooks rice fine but what takes me 15 minutes on a stovetop takes 50!!! minutes in a rice cooker. The rice that comes out is otherwise identical, and the rice cooker takes like 3 minutes longer to clean than my pot does. because it's got more parts. I've clearly missed something here because this is not easier and more convenient for rice cooking, it takes the exact same amount of effort as cooking on stovetop but 4x longer to cook and a little more effort to clean.

So why the hell do people buy these things instead of just cooking on the stove? Is it really so fucking hard to just not lift the lid to stir the rice for 99% of the population or something???

>>18813813
It depends on the type of rice down to the specific cultivar really, but great rice is when you coax the most flavor and desirable texture out of your rice.

If you cook rice exactly the same every time you are not good at cooking rice. As rice ages, and the variance from bag to bag it needs adjustment in the cooking process, mainly more or less water.

If you aren't critically assessing the rice you mads, and thinking of how you can try to improve it the majority of the time you aren't even on the path of achieving great rice. You're merely using it as an easy filler food.

Rice is easy to cook, difficult to perfect.

Rice cookers are convenient because they hold the rice at a warm temperature after they are done and you literally can't fuck it up unless you mismeasure. It's one task that no longer requires your attention at all(whereas stovetop rice requires you to at least be minimally aware and can be burnt). Many people are very anxious in the kitchen, so they overvalue the idiot-proof nature of the rice cooker.

That being said, if you eat rice every day they are great. A good rice cooker can not only cook perfect rice without effort, it can also hot hold it all day, and reheat leftover rice perfectly.

Personally, I mostly eat Basmati rice at home, so I just boil it like pasta if I want plain rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813853
>>18814657
No, the previous anon is 100% correct. I cook over 90 litres of sushi rice a week and the amount of water required to get the correct consistency varies from an even 1/1 ratio to 1/1.25 depending on the crop. As we get later in the season it gets drier and drier. Me and the sushi chef taste every single batch. It needs to have a specific firmness, and the release of starch also needs to be controlled so it's slightly sticky, meaning that I also vary the amount of rice conditioner and the time I spend rinsing it. The quality of the rice also varies along what proportion of the rice grains are broken; with higher proportions from lower quality crops(like the most recent Calrose crop) requiring additional rinsing as the broken grains release more starch,

>>18820882
Here you go:

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.


I THINK that the uneven flame/heat creates "heat turbulence" along with the specific shape of the pot. I haven't actually researched it all that much, so if anyone knows any better chime in please.

>>18825199
Look at instructions on bag of rice
do what it says for stovetop
rice comes out as expected

It's usually something like this:
1. add rice (you can prewash it but who gives a fuck you're making rice)
2. add equal amounts of water
3. turn on the heat until it starts boiling, uncovered (or boil the water before adding the rice who cares)
4. Once it boils turn the heat down to 1 for a simmer and cover it
5. wait 10 minutes
6. rice is done

If you care any further about how the rice tastes or looks go spend $10,000 on a dilator for your gaping front hole

>cooking good food for others gives me a sense of purpose
I don't think this can sustain your drive to be a line cook by itself. You won't be like, simmering a nice stew that you lovingly worked on to serve to someone you hope will enjoy it, you'll be putting out dishes literally as fast as possible while adhering to a quality standard. Restaurant dishes are all about timing and order of operations management. Being a good cook isn't even the most fundamental thing because you need to be very fast and organized. There's a pretty limitless skill ceiling too since a lot of the time you can inprove everyone's night by being really cognizant of everything everyone else is doing and heeding off problems before they even happen or noticing other people's mistakes or what they've forgotten. Who you work with makes the biggest difference but if you're no good you'll struggle anywhere because people who are slow or incompetent really do drag everyone else down, but you would be given time to learn by any decent chef.

>>18829257
>>18829269
These are the right answers. No one is walking around with a compendium of cocktail recipes in their head. This isn't the 1950's.

Just figure out a simple cocktail that you like and stick with it everywhere you go. Don't ask for a mojito, don't ask for something gay and stupid like a singapore sling that has six ingredients. If the bartender has to touch three bottles for a cocktail, they will hate you. Don't ask for anything with red bull. Don't ask for long island iced tea unless you're in a club setting (if you don't know the difference between a club, a pub, a bar, a cocktail lounge, etc, then don't ask for a long island iced tea).

If it's a reasonably okay bar, just ask for a rum daiquiri if you want something refreshing and light. It's delicious. Rum, lime, sugar syrup, shaken hard and served ice cold. If you want something boozier and more.. "manly", ask for a Manhattan or an old fashioned. If you want something manageable that you can sip on for a while, get a highball, which is spirit + carbonated liquid: vodka soda, gin and tonic, tequila soda, whiskey soda. You can just ask for a Jameson highball and the bartender will know what you mean.

You can always ask for a whiskey on the rocks or neat and the bartender will totally respect you for it, especially if it's a nice whiskey. You'll need to specify by brand. Doesn't ask for "whiskey on the rocks", that's what fucking alcoholics and retards ask for.

Don't ask for doubles. Don't ask a bartender to "make it strong". Just order a drink like a real, normal human being who isn't a total retard and is visiting earth for the first time ever.

My usual drink order is a Victoria (mexican beer) and a fernet (italian amaro, very bitter, very unique). A boilermaker or "shot and a beer" is a common combo that will put your bartender at ease.

>>18829113
Try blanched green beans in salted water. Pull one out when they turn bright green and taste test. Quench them in cold water or ice water before they turn soft. They are delicious cold and you will end up eating a handful of them every time you open the fridge. But you can try to keep enough around for sautéing or stir frying.

Cabbage and bacon, shredded cabbage sautéed in butter, coleslaw, sauerkraut–there are too many delicious things to do with cabbage to list. The rabbit hole goes deep.

Yes, brussels sprouts are incredible. On simple days I like to cut in half and pan fry them flat side down in butter, then add salt and black pepper, but you can use any fat. Or roast them in any combo of bacon fat, olive oil, butter, etc. Salt, pepper, garlic or anything. Go all out with a balsamic reduction finish.

Creamed spinach is also excellent (frozen works great). Sautéed or grilled mushrooms, yellow squash/zucchini are nice. Choose the vegetables in season. You'll know by the low prices.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829225
Broccoli is practically a superfood. If you're eating it once a week in stir fries you're fine. More than that you're fine. Don't listen to retarded articles on buzzfeed.

Vegetables basically take on the flavor of whatever you cook them with. Pick something new and find a recipe with it, or use them as a side. Most vegetables are simple and require simple preparation. Some basic suggestions:
Mushrooms - fry them in butter and garlic, or get some portobellos (the big ones) and stuff them with things you like and bake. Toss in dried shiitake to your ramen of choice + bok choy for easy upgrade.
Root vegetables for roasting/baking - add any mix of your favorite seasonings i.e cumin, chili flakes, s/p, rosemary/thyme and roast till cooked/crispy.
Lentil/beans can easily replace beef in certain recipes/cuisines. Canned for ease of use. Learn how to make chili.
Greens can be steamed and drizzled with olive oil, lemon juice and s/p. Or soy sauce, sesame oil/seeds if asian inspired. Kewpie sesame mayo is a godsend. Just throw in any leafy greens to whatever you're cooking for lazy vitamins.

Of these, MS Pot Roast and Kielbasa are the quickest. Ofc you can reduce the types of chopped vegs in the others to shave off prep time or buy in smaller pieces (small pots., baby carrots, pre-minced garlic, chopped onions).
Pot Roast : chopped onions, potatos, carrots, celery, garlic, preferred seasonings; add 2-4 lb. roast, 1 cup beef broth or red wine; 10 hours on low, 6 on high
Mississippi Pot Roast (even simpler) : add 3-4 lb. roast; jar of pepperocinis on top including juice; set stick of butter on top; on top pour 1 packet each of au jus, ranch mix; 10 hours on low
Beef Stew : same as Pot Roast, but use chopped stew meat, add 1 Tblsp. worcestershire sauce; 8 hours on low, 5 hours on high
Kielbasa & Sauerkraut : about 28 oz sauerkraut; large kielbasa ring on top, pour 12 oz bottle dark lager or brown ale such as Munich Dunkel or Vienna Lager; 8 hours on low, 4 on high

>Lustau sherry
Isn't that not even legally sherry in Europe? Like in the U.S. I think that's something like $12 a bottle, which for most people (not all) makes it just about drinkable, briefly, before you use it for cooking. The whiskeys are just all $25--35 range depending on where you shop, and are usually recommended as "introductory" or beginner affordable bottles. Also, there are several bartending guides which note that the required markup for using top-shelf liquors in cocktails is only a few cents per drink (coming to maybe a half to a dollar total altogether), which is a fixed cost where most of the markup for the cocktail is for labor, maintenance, and paying to keep the doors open -- so when you do the microeconomics correctly the customer should only pay that 50 cents extra per drink if you use top-shelf liquor, regardless of how cheap or expensive your bar is in general. In theory that's a price every customer would be happy to pay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829178
If you followed the posts, I've only been practicing for like two months. And subtract a week with family plus a week stressing about it. Plus I'm only practicing every other day lately because I'm tired a lot and don't feel like drinking.

I grew up on wine. Learned a bit about tequila from a good liquor store and started really liking that. Went to a tasting class on fortified wines. But never thought about mixing until I went with a friend to a reasonably fancy bar (all bars are expensive in my area of the city) and had no idea what to order, so the bartender suggested an Old Fashioned. I was amazed by how good it was, and so (after the pandemic) I started looking for whiskey tastings and tried making OFs myself with the starter whiskey brand that was recommended (Four Roses, but I think if you're relatively experienced with wines and spirits in general just get a rye -- you don't need to be eased in with tacky sweet vanilla). I've been basing future purchases on reviews from a few reviewers who I seem to understand their attitude and what they're conveying in writing (for example, the main guy on DrinkHacker is explicit about not preferring reposado tequilas, which is a view I don't necessarily share, so I can adjust my evaluation of his reviews to my taste).

Finally, while I haven't been reading much in books, there's a cult favorite in the amateur internet that certainly has been really helpful for me getting started: "The 12 Bottle Bar" by Solmonson & Solmonson. I can't speak to their recipes, but they break down the basics in a really accessible way (I especially liked the bitters + vermouth as salt + pepper analogy).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
20-30 crayfish
½ bunch of dill
1 lemon
1 tbsp. salt
½ tbsp. sugar
1 dl beer
water to cover the crayfish
COURSE OF ACTION
Put water in a saucepan and add dill, salt, sugar and lemon zest. Let it boil for 10 minutes. Bring on the beer.
Wash the crayfish and prepare them.
Then put your crayfish in the pan with the boiling water. Bring them to the boil quickly and let them boil for 1 minute. Remove the pan from the heat and leave them to cool.
Now serve the freshly cooked crayfish on a plate, preferably with toasted bread, mayonnaise and dill on the side.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18825643
Basically >>18825930

Eggs and potatoes were poor staples diffused in all over the world for centuries, it's hard to collocates that dish in some country

The dish either has a particular set of steps/transformation (like paella) or use a particular ingredient you don't find in other cuisine or it's not used in that specific dish

Like "frittata di lampascioni" is the same identical concept as tortilla de patata but it uses https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopoldia_comosa instead of potatoes, which is an ingredient consumed pretty much only in Italy and Greece

Hence frittata di lampascioni is clearly part of Italian cuisine, tortilla de patatas is more a non territorial dish

enjoy. crawfish season is right around the corner for us and i can't wait.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First impression tea notes:
2020 Jinggu (200g)
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/936595693/2020-jinggu-200g

Parameters:
12.2g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with short steeps

Taste:
Green bean, a bit green teaish in character (despite having some reddish tinged leaves suggesting some oxidation).
Some of the more traditionally shengy tart apricot and pear flavors.
Moderate bitterness and astringency (I have not had green tea for awhile but again this tea feels like it has a bit of green tea character to it in the way it goes down).
Relatively straightforward but pleasant and easy to drink.

Conclusion:
Seems like a fairly priced daily drinker young sheng, especially if you like a bit of green tea character. Probably a decent cake for newcomers to young sheng as well. At 200g/$20 I don't have any substantial complaints. Though if you dislike green bean taste you may want to stay away.

The internet says it's a yellow tea, I would first try a similar yellow tea. Otherwise, yellow tea is closest to green tea, puerh is probably a poor fit.
https://yunnansourcing.com/products/certified-organic-yunnan-yellow-tea
Note that I haven't specifically tried this, I would prefer one bud one leaf to bud only in this case, and it's cheaper as well. Most people don't really drink yellow tea, I'd order this, potentially this and the bud only tea, and see where you're at. As a bonus, I'd probably throw in some chinese green tea as well.
Mandala tea also aparantly sells some, I also haven't (and probably wouldn't) tried this.

I have actually had that tea a few years back. It is effectively a more lightly oxidized black tea. I recall it having kind of a nice orange marmalade and almond biscotti flavor but also that it could get quite bitter if over brewed (like a lot of black tea).

>>18811219
>I would prefer one bud one leaf to bud only in this case, and it's cheaper as well.
Besides price why? I did not have the pure bud version but I suspect it may be slightly better because the buds will highlight some of that teas lighter more floral elements better over the bitter "maltiness". I do do doubt it is twice as good though so it is not going to be as good of value.
https://yunnansourcing.com/collections/yunnan-sourcing-brand-certified-organic-teas/products/certified-organic-emperors-yellow-yunnan-yellow-tea

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
matcha ice cream:
2qt half & half
12 egg yolks
2 cup sugar or 1 cup erythritol 1 cup allulose (or xylitol) or 2 cup erythritol if eating within 48 hours
matcha (doesn't matter, the sugar and cream is gonna murder any subtleties of the leaf)
25 dollar walmart churn https://www.walmart.com/ip/Nostalgia-4-Quart-Electric-Ice-Cream-Maker-Blue/749542584
big boxes of salt

1. make matcha with the half & half. it honestly doesn't matter how much you make, i've used just fuck my shit up levels and it was perfectly fine. it just has to dissolve
2. put a metal bowl on the stove and dump everything in it. remember to break yolks. add pinch of salt. turn the heat to maximum and stir it
3. you can do this until either the sugar is fully dissolved or to official guideline which is like 150F to kill salmonella. use infrared thermometer and remember what temperature you turned the heat off at for next time
4. dump ice cream custard into ice cream maker cylinder and put it in the fridge for a few hours
5. make lots of ice sitting in the freezer the day before
6. put cylinder in bucket, put paddle in cylinder, put motor on, dump layer of ice, layer of salt till it's full and plug in
7. churn for about 20-30 min or until it fails to churn. if you used sugar or plain erythritol, it's ready to eat. if you used erythritol with alluose (or xylitol), it needs a day or two in the freezer to get firmer. the bottom is usually ready though.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18819787
Higher fermentation, darker tastes, more mellow, more rounded out, if fermented properly they are ready to drink much sooner, don't benefit much from aging.
Lighter fermentation, more likely to be bitter, retains more of the teas original character, less rounded and smoothed out, the really lightly fermented stuff needs a pretty solid aging period before its ready to drink, but they haven't produced much like that since the early 2000s and further back.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18822295
That doesn't apply to shou puerh, shou was developed in the 70s to mimic the taste of aged sheng. The whole point is that it needs to be drinkable immediately, without aging. It doesn't actually taste like aged sheng, but it certainly doesn't benefit in the same way from aging, although properly stored aged shou can be pretty good. This will not happen in your pumidor. Young sheng was the only puerh that was drunk for most of history, young sheng is still what is drunk today in Puer. Aged puerh was a market that was created to shift the large amounts of stock of puerh that existed primarily in Hong Kong to Taiwan, it spread from there. Similarly to shou, however, if you have a bing or batch of maocha that doesn't taste very good, it's bad tea. Aging will not fix it, because the tea is simply bad. If you age good tea, the flavor will transform as the years pass, and if you store it properly, it can improve significantly. You cannot do this with bad tea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18822431
"designed for aging" just means that the tea isn't processed as green as people might be used to. The tea should still taste good young. Parts of the world, primarily Taiwan, HK, Guangdong, don't really drink young sheng. That doesn't mean that young sheng is undrinkable, or that it's acceptable for it to have any of the flaws you'd usually assosciate with bad tea. Flat taste, high bitterness, weak liquor, or any obvious defects like it being murky from oversteaming, toasted or burnt, etc. The tea commonly drunk on whatever your preferred tea mountain is, Jingmai, Yiwu, whatever, could also be aged as is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18825706
Roiboos all comes from one farming collective in africa. So basically no matter where you buy it from its comming from the same farms and blended in the same warehouse for export. Freshness will make the biggest difference in quality. I also think it does better with short steeping times. 60-90 seconds. Mountain rose herbs should have straight unflavored roiboos and its cousin Honeybush which i think is better personally, it's extremely sweet but again keep brew times short for best results.
For mate you want to buy the proper south American brands, you can find them on places like amazon.
Some super premium brands are mate & co and Anna Park. More reasonably priced brands look for La Merced, for more affordable brands rosamonte especial and cruz de malta.
There is a lot of variety with taste and flavors between brands, some are sweeter, some more bitter, some smoked. You need to try some and figure out what you like if you want to get into it.

I don't know about a universal litmus test but a few things I look for in an inexperienced cook that tell me they still have basics to know
>adding oil to a cold pan, THEN heating the pan, scorching the oil
>adding garlic too early or even first when sautéing vegetables or searing meats
>Not knowing how to properly cut/peel/dice an onion
>doesn't use different oils for different tasks
There are plenty more, but these are my most common telltale signs of inexperienced cooks imo

This is basically what I came here to say. If someone has taken the time to pay even minimal attention to how things in a kitchen are done "correctly", then they will very likely also care about how their food turns out. Over the course of a number of years, their dishes should casually turn out at least decent even when they aren't particularly trying.
People that don't know shit about cooking only have good meals when they get super lucky or they are relying entirely on the couple recipes they learned from a parent or friend that they do over and over and are fucked if something goes wrong during the preparation.
It's also why I appreciate women who are proud bakers, because while I'm not particularly crazy about baked good desserts, I know that it means they pay attention to what they're doing and have the patience to iterate. Successful and reliable baking requires a lot of tweaking of individual recipe components, and someone who doesn't care about cooking won't know where to start (or where to look to get started) on making adustments to a recipe that underperformed on the first pass.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18826025
they understand temperature and how their pans react to their stovetop, they don't scorch oil and aren't afraid of a smoky kitchen, have good varieties of spice around their cooking area they clearly use frequently, and aren't afraid of using lots of fat in their cooking. Even if they use shitty store bought premade things a bit of care and technique can make a mediocre home chef produce food better than a mediocre linecook with ease

but the biggest tells are:
1.do they have a decent variety of meals they can cook that all cover major food groups and are well seasoned?
2. do they actually know how to cook the meat they're working with or just use it as a filler protein? (example: people who cook chicken thighs on the stove and wonder why they're chewy and unpleasant tasting, showing they don't know that the interconnective tissue needs to be cooked slowly first)
3. do they understand how to get a good sear? or, if they're using shitty glass stovetops and can't, do they know about using flour dredges and temperature management to get a good enough one?
4. do they own a dutch oven that they use? do they brown their slow cooked meat before letting it simmer, or are they one of those faggot morons that just lets massive chunks of fatty meat simmer in a crockpot making the kitchen smell awful
5. are they afraid of smoke in the kitchen? this is the biggest tell if someone isn't a good cook, if they panic when a nonstick pan starts to smoke then theyre not a good cook nor do they have any experience

>>18827852
>grind the salt yourself
Why would you do that? There's no aromatics sealed in the salt crystals that are released on grinding. It's fucking salt. Plus, by grinding them you'll get nonuniform grain sizes. The whole point of using (iodized or not, it doesn't matter) table salt (aka baking salt) is that the grains are roughly a consistent average size across manufacturers for a good century, making it usable by volume in baking recipes.

Kosher salt (or large-grained salt -- it literally doesn't matter whether it's kosher, iodized, or comes out of my asshole, as long as it's all salts of which 95+% or so are NaCl) is ubiquitous outside of baking because you can control it much more easily by hand, and it generally has a wider margin of error.

Since this is our first /ssg/ lets start off with a little history.

It has been estimated that as much as two-thirds of deceased soldiers in the US Civile War were killed not by bullets but by disease, with the most prevalent of those diseases being the intestinal illnesses diarrhea and dysentery. It was not clear, based on the established medical knowledge, exactly what caused these illnesses to flourish in military camps, but one physician by the name of James H. Salisbury suspected diet was the greatest culprit, and came up with his own solution.

He believed vegetables and starchy foods produced poisonous substances in the digestive system which were responsible for heart disease, tumors, mental illness and tuberculosis. He believed that human dentition demonstrated that humans were meant to eat meat, and sought to limit vegetables, fruit, starches, and fats to one-third of the diet.

The Salisbury steak, his means of achieving this goal, is ground beef flavored with onion and seasoning and then deep-fried or boiled and covered with gravy or brown sauce. It was introduced in 1888. Salisbury saw beef as an excellent defense against many different physical problems. He suggested that Salisbury steak should be eaten three times a day, with much hot water to cleanse the digestive system. He was an early American proponent of a low-carbohydrate diet for weight loss, and he promoted his diet for that purpose. His diet became known as the "Salisbury diet".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>so much time
It takes me, like, 10-15 minutes to process 1kg of 'chokes for cooking. I err on the side of caution here as I suspect it takes me significantly less time than that.
Is that "so much time?" Compared to shit like, say, celery or courgettes, sure, that's a while, but I don't think it's that long, really.

And depending on what you do with them and which variety you're using, they very much could be "worth it." Where I'm from, we hollow out the middle of longer artichokes, the ones without the spikey part of the leaves, and stuff it with cheese, garlic, parsley and the 'choke's own stem then drizzle with oil and roast it until done. Another dish is to wedge and clean pretty much any variety (leafless artichoke is even better) of 'choke then saute in oil with garlic, olives and parsley and serve toss with spaghetti. Yet another is battered and deep-fried. For large, spherical artichokes, the typical steam it and dip the leaves in oil thing is most common, but they can also be stuffed, although this time with bits of stale bread cooked in oil with aromatics and a bit of broth (or just breadcrumbs and cheese).
Leafless artichoke is really good made into a savoury pie. And, of course, most varieties are great in paella.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813702
>having to pay your interns
This is baffling to me. The economics are just very strange. For example, many young people looking to further their academic careers but failed to get into a paid PhD program would be willing, if able, to do research unpaid, or even pay for another year of education in the interim before applying again. And yet those hyper-competitive PhD programs still pay salaries (in some form) to their students. However, less-competitive programs do not seem to try to compete with other programs for better students by offering higher salaries, as would be expected in a competitive marketplace, even if they receive a windfall of funding. Part of it's a very intense social psychology for sure -- money is not really supposed to be a motivator -- but at the same time you obviously don't want to shut out, or force extra work upon, those who can't simply live on a parental stipend.

This world of top-tier restaurant internships, and many other classy internships, in theory seems like it should work with at least a somewhat similar mindset -- at least at a certain point the interns should be intrinsically qualified and valuable enough to be paid and competed over, else why have interns in the first place?

It kind of reminds me of that famous 19th-century economist's prediction that the most menial worker's wages would always fall to the bare minimum needed to sustain life. Obviously it's not true in an actual labor market, but doesn't it seem to be even worse in the internship market?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18819923
>an entire means to get work experience
It's called getting an education, showing competence in your school performance, and getting an entry-level job (with entry salary and prestige of the company often, but not always commensurate to said school performance).

Unpaid internships encourage a reduction in the number, quality, and pay inentry level positions, and the ubiquity of them in certain fields also makes the educational quality of the internships vary heavily -- and due to the very nature of internships being outside a school, this quality may have zero oversight.

To expand: it is the norm in industry X (civil engineering or culinary arts, say) to have unpaid internships during and/or shortly after graduation. The number of such students seeking internships is so high that companies with even barely a moderate size or prestige attached have zero trouble consistently having many more qualified candidates applying for internships than they could accept even if they wanted. Many long-lived well-managed firms are high quality and see internships as investing in future hires, and take the education of all interns seriously. However, there are many more mediocre companies than these, and they will often defer interns to low-level staff, who may only devote time to actually educating a handful, while, as is *very stereotypical* relegating the *vast majority* to "coffee duty". They can do this because, again, there are usually many more applicants every year than there are positions. And as a company is not paying interns, which is by nature an investment, there is no incentive for retention, promotion, development, etc.

And this is only looking at part of the problem. Unpaid internships are an inherently inefficient, exploitative, uneconomical system.

>A 6 month internship at Noma or the French Laundry is worth much more than a 4 year degree from CIA.
You obviously didn't see a prior thread from last week where OP linked an article where a former recounted her experience at the world's best restaurant -- the first 3 years were spent simply preparing perfect jelly molds into the shape of beetles. (The article was not primarily about that, but that's what we gravitated to.)

As I detailed, an unpaid internship often isn't worth shit except for a few students, often selected not by their merit but by the luck of the motivation of whichever lowest-level manager is tasked to supervise them. Because the company makes zero financial investment, they have no incentive to oversee the training interns (unless they specifically have an internship-to-career-develop program in place, or their upper management sees education and economic development in general as a long-term investment strategy.).

To take an example from engineering, I know for a fact there are companies who have as an informal policy to make those in their first year of internship just to copies and coffee, such that only those who return for a second year (thus "proving company loyalty" or some shit? What did they do to earn loyalty? I guess you're just proving loyalty to whoever offers you another internship in spite of shitty grades, or whoever promises steady employment in an area you want to live) get to do actual developmental work.

In part this is facilitated by universities competing to get exclusive internship slots for students at big-name companies, but for the most part it wouldn't be possible if at the end of the day the internships were not unpaid.

posts.com: Some people have said some pans heat more evenly on burners with uneven heat (like electric). What properties of the pan makes certain ones heat more evenly than others? Wouldn't eventually there always be a hot spot corresponding to the burner's hot spots?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18828077
Materials with high heat retention (cast iron and carbon steel) can be pre-heated to a point where the variation becomes neglible. It's losing less heat than it's taking in, so is heating up its colder spots faster than it is cooling. This near equilibrium will then tend to be maintained when you add dry ingredients, unless the ingredients are very cold. Unheated liquids will remove heat more rapidly due to covering so much area. You'll also want to give the pan a little time to heat back up after emptying it if you're going to put something else in.

A good stainless steel pan can also achieve even heat distribution by using the low thermal conductivity of the stainless steel to delay the more efficient heat output of the core until fuller distribution is achieved.

posts.com:
To check which grains are bad, just see if any of them are floating while they soak. Discard those and you're good.
Also, the soaking is mostly to stop you from farting the whole day.
To actually make them taste good, stir fry some onion and/or garlic in your preferred fat, salt it and put the beans and cover with water. You can add a bay leaf if you have any.
As for the cooking time, just pressure cook them for 45 min and you're done.

Hey guys.

I wanted to make something for dinner. I was looking at what I had. Things like pre-cooked pierogis, frozen. loaf breads and cold cut processed meats like salamis. They're so full of additives and sadness. So I wanted to make something myself. I see potatoes, and they're solid food, so I'll use them.

I go to the internet looking for good potato recipes. Baked potato, etc. They're all so complex, so many steps and bloated instructions, random ingredients (paprika??) and took forever.

I decide to boil them :) Boil 2 small-medium gold potatoes. Put in 2 or 3 tbsp butter, some milk till it's kinda soupy. Add some flour if it's too thin maybe, and then salt and pepper? does that sound like it will be good? I'm still cooking them, they're boiling right now.

here's a photo. sorry for shit quality, i have to use my laptop camera because i removed the internet off of my phone haha

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
American opinions on food are worthless, as they have never became accustomed to eating decebt quality produce on a regular basis, so they can only remember tastes partially and need to categorize everything they eat because otherwise they cannot tellthe difference.
For example, all the talk about mexican vs chinese vs italian vs whatever, when you come to it all these cuisines have completely different ways of preparing different ingredients. French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Greek, Thai, Viet, etc all have a method of preparing a big pot of boiled meat and vegetables. It's mostly the same dish with different details. Yet americans cannot conceive that mexican food doesn't have shitty "cheese", that italian food doesn't have tomato sauce, that chinese food doesn't have wok fried stuff, that french food doesn't have butter, etc. Since americans mostly lack experience travelling to other countries and not eatin only at tourists traps, they think each country is the caricature they are exposed to when they go to shitty restaurants. Just like they think italians eat meatballs because it's there in italian restaurants and that chinese food is what they eat at those chain takeout places. The most adventurous of them just go to youtube and then they think youtibe is the faithful representation of another country, so in essence they are still ignorant but in a different way.
Obviously, living in the largest economy in the world provides little incentive to explore other economies, because of the fake sense that there can't be anything better out there.
And that is why I never take an american's opinion on food seriously. All those american youtube cooks are frauds, you just unfortunately don't know any better.

>>18822064
>If you ask a Japanese person what is Italian food, they think of tomato sauce, pasta and cheese. If you ask an Italian what is American food, they'll think of barbecue and burgers. If you ask an Argentinian about Japanese food, they'll think of sushi.

This might be true, but these cultures are used t eating good quality produce; that is the first thing mentioned in that post. Americans on average only eat incredibly low quality vegetables and protein since they were kids; they haven't built an expectation for what good ingredients taste like. The chlorinated chicken, the refrigerated eggs, the GMO vegetables, they all compromise flavor for something else.

It's the reason why Americans interested in gastronomy are genuinely surprised when they do travel abroad and eat simple food and it tastes great. In these other cultures, when we make a simple dish we expect it to be tasty like our good memories of it, and we get pissed of when the courgette, carrot, tomato, sea bream, shrimp, turkey leg, etc is of poor quality. For americans, that's the norm. That's why Americans regularly cite eating some extremely simple yet tasty dish X at country Y as a life changing experience. American society sacrificed love and respect for food as a cultural phenomenon in lieu of abundance and excess availability. Obviously a few americans are against that and try to go down the other path, but I imagine it's almost impossible to become accustomed to something that just isn't as easily available (quality ingredients).

continued below

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18823856
continued

For example, in my country of Portugal I can buy fresh Iberico pig meat for 13€/kg. And fresh wild atlantic fatty fish (sea bream, sea bass, mackerels, snappers, flat fishes, mullet etc) around 10€ or less (closer to 20€ for sea bass, it's rarer now). For example, my favorite meal is fresh fish grilled on charcoal with salt, olive oil and garlic. Put a wild sea bass on the charcoal grill and its fat is so naturally delicious that you will slobber yourself if it's cooked to the right temperature. I love fancy meals wit technique, but in terms of pure deliciousness, the great ingredients are already 90% as they will ever be when cooked in simple ways. For americans, this empirical fact is often a "lesson" the learn when they go abroad, because it's not a common occurrence in their country.

>>18824519
my egg bake was tasty, it was yummy, it was delicious, it was spicy, and it was fluffy. It was tasty as always, but not as well fried as it could be. The sauce seemed to be making you want to stir well, which is nice to have included, but no way I could believe that something that so obviously is the real deal in any other bakery. Instead, I used a homemade butter sauce which actually tastes better (after I cooked it in a pre-drying pan for an hour before I added more of the ingredients to it) and that adds a beautiful texture to the cake. It's one of those cake cakes, and I'm super super thankful for it. But seriously, who doesn't love something delicious and decadent?! It's so sweet!! It's even delicious with the sauce!! I'm all, "Can this be?" (although I wouldn't want it to be!! No worries, I know this cake tastes great on it's own anyway.) After all, I was really making it up a while ago , so what were the odds that this was going to get posted in the popular "popular" recipe community. So this is what I do myself. So I'm hoping this is a place for you guys because now we've got a real foodie who understands how to make some delicious homemade cakes

I’ll admit it here in an anonymous fashion just to get this off my chest. I was bribed to delete the footage by an unknown contact from within the main factory area that produced the berries. I worked at that job for about 4 years since I met all the qualifications and it paid well, but the sum of money that guy offered me? If I had taken that, I could’ve had a crunch factory of my own. I couldn’t take the bribe though, as the Cap’n himself had heard of the plot beforehand from what I know, and I think he could’ve gotten suspicious of me had I taken the bribe and fulfilled that obligation. I didn’t want to have his goons hunt me down if I took it and dipped outta there, either, you feel me?

I remember the day of the incident. I was in the camera room as usual when all of the screens went red all of the sudden. A big buzzing noise emitted from them as well, with this interference lasting upwards of about 4 minutes. It only ended when a huge explosion was heard.

The security room was positioned to where it had its own emergency door, so every one of the workers started rushing out through that one after it had happened. I never got a good look at ground zero of the incident due to the sudden crowd that blocked me, but the cameras had returned to show absolutely nothing after the blast, and once we all evacuated, we were told nothing.

I was laid off a day later by the cap’n, reportedly for false sexual harassment claims that he framed me for. As such, I don’t know much more, but I hope this info was useful. If I don’t reply to anyone by later today, he’s already got me.

posts.com: I honestly don't know the answer. It's just not something most Americans would even think of. We eat bread with butter, and buttered toast/bagels/english muffins/biscuits, but the only time we ever really put butter on a sandwich is if it's on the outside and we're toasting it. We usually just use mayo and mustard for most things. It's not like we have inferior bread and butter; it's just not a thing we do. I lived in France for a while and one of the things that honestly surprised me the most was people would actually butter their bread before eating cheese with it. Like, holy shit dude, I know baguettes and cheese and wine are kind of your thing, but do you really need to butter your bread before adding that 2 ounce dollop of epoisses?

>>18819296
4 cups whole wheat flour
Pint of water
Yeast pack
Tablespoon honey
Teaspoon salt

Proofed yeast with honey in the warmed water, then mixed with the flour and salt (which I had sifted together). Kneaded it until it was plump and well incorporated
Let rise for an hour covered by a hot damp towel, rewarmed towel and placed dough in a bread tin and let it rise for another hour. Baked for 15 minutes at gas mark 7 (425F), then for another 40 minutes at gas mark 4 (350F).

The lady selling it plopped it on a paper plate and microwaved it for me. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820505
Hotdog stands in denmark, they are unlike any other hotdogs and it's so difficult to place, I've tried so many dog types and sausages but they're not the same. they also have pickled cucumbers that aren't like regular pickles. there was this remolade yellow sauce that tasted like a really refined big mac sauce. I ate so many of them when I visited and they had stands literally everywhere. It's almost scary how common they are. Stayed a couple nights on the coast in a really rural part. it had like one store for groceries within 20 miles and no other commerce aside from farms. Even in that remote old people place there was still a god damn hot dog trailer that would park outside the grocery every day. I swear you could go hiking in the forest, go off the beaten trail, fall into a ravine and find a hotdog stand at the bottom of it. Only visited once though, so maybe I just had crazy luck.
it's unique because I've never called a hotdog "refreshing" but that's the best way I could describe it.

https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/wolfgang-pucks-recipe-for-pizza-dough-1908603

Follow this recipe, it’s pretty good and easy.
4 balls for 8”, I Personally do 3 balls for close to 12”

The most important part I’ve found is not fucking up your proofing, you need a thermometer and to temp that hot water before throwing in the yeast, it’s easy to kill your yeast.

Also I always tend to add more olive oil to the balls when rolling them out. Not sure why my dough has a tendency of being too dry/snap backs instead of laying flat. But a dab of oil when rolling out leaves it moist and flat, cooks really well.

I have some dough rising right now I’m going to make some pizza around noon today

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813328
Take a basic lean bread recipe. 5/3 flour to water. For 20oz of flour, use 2tsp salt, 1/2tsp yeast, and 1oz olive oil(don't buy it at the grocery store, grocery store oil is adulterated and rancid, regardless of what the bottle says).

Literally just mix this all together into a dough ball, then need it until the dough is smooth and you can stretch part of it thin enough light passes through.

Then portion it into however many pizzas you are making, and ball it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oZxNbL5XB7w

Then shove each dough ball in an oiled, sealed container that's big enough to allow it to expand, then shove those containers in the fridge for 48 hours.

Come back, let them warm up enough to work with, and then stretch them out. The dough should be quite thin, 1/3 an inch, with a bit more on the edges.

>>18813328
Use yellow corn meal on your pizza peel to slide your raw pizza around.
Everyone says use flour, and it works fine, but corn meal gives extra texture and taste, it’s great when charred a bit. Stole this from a local restaurant chain.

You want truly great pizza at home?
Smoke it.
Throw a pizza steel/stone in your pitboss pellet grill, preheat it HOT and cook it in there. Pizza steel in the oven works fine, but the smoked cheese and crust from the pitboss makes pizza exponentially better. And you don’t heat the kitchen up with 550degree oven.

Don’t have a pellet grill yet? Fucking buy one, it’s 2023 and they are everywhere.

kneading high hydration dough by hand is a waste of time. it will form a strong gluten network by itself over a period of several hours (google autolysis). all you had to do was wait - you could have simply tossed it in the refrigerator overnight - but your impatience and inexperience got the best of you. 5 minutes by hand is approximately nothing. I knead my pasta dough for around 10 minutes and pasta dough builds gluten very quickly. for a pizza dough you're looking at 30-60 minutes of hand kneading depending on exactly how wet your dough is, what type of flour you are using, and what additions you're using.
>>18813940
yeah he used a mixer with a dough hook. if you don't have a machine to do the kneading then you're better off just letting the gluten build up naturally through autolysis. wet dough responds very slowly to kneading, you could easily spend an hour by hand to get the level of gluten development he got in just a few minutes on the machine, or you could just give it a few folds every hour for a few hours and get the same result with a lot less work.

Why would you want it to rise before putting it in the freezer like it's the oven? There's absolutely no point to that. It's better to freeze an unrisen dough. Not only does it take up less room in the freezer but any air bubbles will collapse in the freezer anyway due to negative thermal expansion. When you freeze anything you should have it sealed in an airtight bag and press out any air that you can.

posts.com:
I've had good luck with my pizza's recently. I use this recipe...

3 cups of flour (2 white 1 wheat or all white)
3 tsp yeast (standard red star stuff you can get in most grocery stores.
Optional: a tbsp or two of sugar
1-2 cups of HOT HOT, but not boiling, water

First: You'll need a baking stone in the oven.

Methodology, flour and yeast in bowl, mix / fluff (you could also just sift). Add one cup of water mix throughout with your hand until fully absorbed. Start adding small amounts of water and repeat the mixing until you get large clumps that are not sticky to the touch. Knead until all flour in incorporated and the dough is slightly sticky. Leave it alone for 20 minutes. Come back and turn dough into ball (the one you see all the pro chefs do on youtube). Then cover in a dusting of flour and bag the bowl or put a lid on it.

Now you wait at least one hour, but preferably an afternoon or so before rolling it out and putting toppings on it.

To cook it; turn the oven on 30-60 minutes before the pizza goes in and turn it on high. Like 500 F. Top pizza, put in for 5 minutes, turn and check on cheese / crust, cook for another 4-5 minutes and take out.

>>18813328
>teach me how to make a good pizza dough
For an 18" crust :
1 US cup of water
Yeast (1 tbsp or so)
Olive oil (1/4 cup or less)
Salt (1 tbsp or less)
Flour

Mix all this together. You'll need enough flour to get the dough just sticky, but not to much. The other measurements are up to taste, really. I always eyeball it.
Kneed - you should have learned this from your mother. Or at school. Watch a YT if you dunno how.
Cover with olive oil, let it rest. A long slow rest at low temp (cook room for 6 hours) will give you a better dough the a short fast rest a higher temp.

Then you will grease your pan and spread out the dough. Or flour a counter top and roll out your dough.

If you want to get fancy, make a pre-ferment : 1 cup flour, 1 cup water, yeast. You mix all this up the night before and let the yeast have fun over night. Add in the oil, salt and rest of the flour the next morning and let it rise all day.

A wetter (aka stickier) dough will make a better crust but will be harder to kneed if you are doing it by hand.

everybody kneads the shit out of their dough but they're doing it wrong so they're just adding extra work for shittier dough

Just mix the ingredients until combined then let sit for 10-15 min and come back and do a few cross folds every 10-15 min afterward for 4-6 time and even the stickiest dough's will be manageable and have much better
>https://youtu.be/6JQm2n4aVZctexture/crumb

picrel is my pizza dough recipe + i oil the bowl that its proofing in so it doesn't stick and i can do the cross folds

#1.mix salt into flour
#2.make dent in flour and add yeast and water, let sit a few min to hydrate yeast
#3.stir until it starts to come together then add oil
#4 stir until combined and the flour is pulling off the sides
#5. Let it rest 15min (covered)
#6. cross fold a few times every 15min for 5 to 7 times (also add some oil to the bowl at this point)
#let it proof on the counter (covered) for 4 up to 12 hours (you'll need a very large bowl with a lid that snaps on tightly )

>>18818753
Shake your pizza as you build it.
Put ample corn meal or wheat on the peel, put your crust on it
Shake it so it slides freely
Put your sauce on
Shake it so it slides freely
Put toppings on, shake it so it slides freely

If at any point it doesnt slide freely, lift up the crust and use a paper towel under it to remove moisture, and then shake it some more.

It should slide like its on ice skates while sitting on your pizza peel.
Make sure you take the sliding into account when topping the pizza, because its going to get launched. Less cheese and toppings you drop the better

posts.com:
Use King Arthur All Purpose or Bread Flour. It kicks the shit out of the other stuff at the grocery store. Get a kitchen scale so you can measure it by weight and control the hydration. 58-62% is what you want. Get a stone or a steel and preheat it for at least 45 minutes. You don't need a mixer. Just stir it together and let it rest for an hour and then do some light kneading to make it smooth. Put it in an oiled container in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours.

Use a dough calculator and make the balls by Thickness Factor. .1 TF is fairly thick, like a chain pizza. .065 is where it is pretty thin.

https://pizzadoughcalculator.vercel.app/calculator
